summary: The authors of this article are asked to share their views on the topic of science writing . The study was published by the University of Melbourne, Australia, and the U.S. Department of Energy Joint Genome Institute .

Teresa E Pawlowska and Yan Wang are authors of the study . The study was published at the University of Toronto Scarborough, Toronto, ON M1C 1A4 .
Researchers from Hakim Sabzevari University, Iran, Australia, and the U.S. Australia, alexander.idnurm@unimelb.edu.au .

The first genome sequenced of a eukaryotic organism was for <em>Saccharomyces cerevisiae in 1996 . Genomic data from these early-diverging terrestrial fungi revealed deep phylogenetic separation of the two major clades .

The number of sequenced fungal genomes continues to grow exponentially . Zygomycete genomes have and will continue to play an integral role in our current understanding of the initial transition of organisms to land .

Axenic cultures remain the preferred and most straightforward method of obtaining high-molecular-weight genomic DNA for sequencing projects . In rare cases, high-quality tissue from field-collected fruiting bodies can be used to generate genomes .

The genomes of species with larger genomes (e.g., taxa in <em>Glomeromycotina</em) are more fragmented . These larger assemblies are due to larger overall genomes and because of difficulties with assembly caused by polyploidy, numerous repeats, and transposons .
Most zygomycete genomes are of species within species within <em>Mucoromycota . As a result, much of what we know about genome evolution among early-diverging fungi comes from this phylum .

Rhizopus is increasingly studied as a model organism thanks to its availability in culture collections and to its important role in biotechnology and human health . For example, there are >220 genomes available for species of <em>Rhizopus .

There are not many genomic sequences of these organisms available due to historical impediments hampering sequencing projects, including multinucleate spores with different genotypes, obligate biotrophy of AMFs, and initial uncertainty concerning genome sizes .
Genes required for plant colonization were found in gene-sparse, repeat-reach compartments [ <a href="#B121-microorganisms-11-01830" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="B120-microorgancynomycota"

Species of <em>Dimargaritales appear to be rare in the environment and have mostly been isolated from dung rather than soil . Genome analyses have highlighted that members of the <em >Dimargaris cristalligena have larger genomes and more predicted secondary metabolite genes .

Smittium is a well-studied genus within <em>Harpellales with approximately 100 described species . There are only nine whole-genome sequences available for these insect gut-dwelling fungi . Comparative genomics revealed a fungus–insect symbiotic core gene toolbox (FISCoG) that is shared among insect-associated fungi .
Despite many genomes from the genus <em>Conidiobolus, there are only a few other species (all from the key family <em]Entomophthoraceae) for which genomes are available .

Mutants impaired in photoresponses, especially phototropism, were isolated in the 1970s . The first genes related to photoressponses were not reported until 2006 . These were identified using a candidate gene approach in which <em>P. blakesleeanus was assumed to have similar blue light sensors as Dikarya .

The application of “omics” tools has been essential in elucidating the molecular underpinnings of the mutualism between <em>Glomeromycotina and their ancient and uncultivable endosymbiont “Candidatus” Glomeribacter gigasporarum” (CaGg, <em) Burkholderi
